newsitem.title: USA: Deregulation to save electric consumers $5.4 bln.
newsitem.headline: Deregulation to save electric consumers $5.4 bln.

text.p: The head of the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission (FERC) late on Thursday said electricity deregulation would save consumers $3.8 billion to $5.4 billion.

"Our conservative estimate is $3.8 (billion) to $5.4 billion per year," FERC chairwoman Elizabeth Moler said at Harvard University's John F. Kennedy School of Government after giving a history of deregulation.
Moler would not specify how those savings in the $200 billion industry would be distributed in California and New England where deregulation was underway.

"When you talk about an industry of this magnitude, it's just a small piece of what's at stake here. If you couple that with state initiatives, the numbers get really big and they grow over time," she said in response to a question.
Moler shied away from any discussion of specific utilities or states' plans for deregulation, saying only: "I don't have any views on the Massachusetts experiment."

She was referring to part of a Boston Edison proposal, submitted to state regulators last spring, showing consumers would not really save money and in the end could actually pay more for electricity. -- Boston bureau, 617-367-4106
